newsitem.title: USA: Applix off after Q4 results, downgrade.
newsitem.headline: Applix off after Q4 results, downgrade.

text.p: Applix Inc shares lost nearly 25 percent of their value Wednesday after reporting slightly lower-than-expected fourth quarter earnings that resulted in one analyst downgrading the stock to buy from strong buy.

The Westboro, Mass.-based supplier of real-time decision support software reported fourth quarter operating earnings of $0.21 a share, before some acquisition-related charges, versus $0.16 per share a year ago. The consensus among the handful of analysts who follow the company had been $0.22 per share.
Needham analyst John Barr cut the stock to buy from strong buy, but kept his earnings estimate of $0.96 a share for 1997.
Applix had declined six points to 16-3/4 by late afternoon on unusually high volume for the stock of 3.2 million shares.

Barr said fourth quarter earnings were hurt by accelerated hiring of sales and marketing staff to beef up the company's distribution of new products it has developed in-house and through recent aquisitions.
He said the downgrade resulted from the fourth quarter earnings disappointment and because of some concern about the slow sequential growth in Applix's decision support products.
But Barr downplayed the recent quarter's shortfall as necessary to ensure future revenue growth and as "a bit of product transition issue."
Soundview analyst Kris Tuttle said the company may take a quarter or two before earnings begin to accelerate again. He maintained his short-term hold and long-term buy on the stock.
Both analysts remained positive on Applix's long-term outlook.
"It's a good quality company. They are highly profitable and growing at 40 percent per year," Tuttle said. "They just came up a little shy of expectations," he said.
The company is known for its real-time decision support software tools including Internet access to stock quotes.
